From Orchards of ample Extent,</br>Pomona's compell'd to depart;</br>And thus, as in Anguish she went,</br>The Goddess unburthen'd her Heart.
To flourish where Liberty reigns,</br>Was all my fond Wishes requir'd;</br>And here I agreed with the Swains,</br>To live, till their Freedom expir'd.
Of late ye have number'd my Trees,</br>And threaten'd to limit my Store:</br>I fear — from such Maxims as these,</br>I fear — that your Freedom's no more.
My Flight will be fatal to May:</br>For how can her Gardens be fine?</br>The Blossoms are doom'd to decay,</br>(The Blossoms, I mean, that were mine.)
Rich Autumn remembers me well:</br>My Fruitage was fair to behold!</br>My Pears! — how I ripen'd their Swell!</br>My Pippins! — were Pippins of Gold!
Let Ceres drudge on with her Ploughs!</br>She droops as she furrows the Soil;</br>A Nectar I shake from my Boughs,</br>A Nectar that softens my Toil.
When Bacchus began to repine,</br>With Patience I bore his Abuse;</br>He said that I plunder'd the Vine,</br>He said that I pilfer'd his Juice.
I know the proud Drunkard denies</br>That Trees of my Culture should grow:</br>But let not the Traitor advise;</br>He comes from the Climes of your Foe.
Alas!  in your Silence I read</br>The Sentence I'm doom'd to deplore:</br>'Tis plain, the great PAN had decreed,</br>My Orchard shall flourish no more.
The Goddess flew off in Despair;</br>As all her sweet Honours declin'd:</br>And PLENTY and PLEASURE declare,</br>They'll loiter no longer behind.</br>
